content.statement: proc-019-femorofemoral is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Procedures that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding proc-019-femorofemoral helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of proc-019-femorofemoral include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of proc-019-femorofemoral.

definitions_glossary.crossover_graft: Graft connecting structures on opposite sides of the body
definitions_glossary.donor_artery: The artery providing inflow for the bypass
definitions_glossary.recipient_artery: The artery receiving flow from the bypass
definitions_glossary.steal_phenomenon: Reduction in flow to donor limb due to bypass taking blood
definitions_glossary.externally_supported_graft: PTFE with external rings to prevent compression

indications: Unilateral iliac artery occlusion with good contralateral flow
Failed iliac angioplasty/stent with good contralateral flow
High-risk patient not suitable for aortoiliac reconstruction
contraindications: Bilateral iliac occlusive disease (need aortic inflow)
Donor iliac stenosis >50% (will steal from donor leg)

technique.positioning: Supine, legs slightly abducted and externally rotated
technique.incisions: Bilateral vertical groin incisions over femoral pulse

graft_selection.alternative: Great saphenous vein (if available, rarely used)

tunnel.plane: Above rectus fascia, below Scarpa's fascia
tunnel.shape: Gentle curve (C or U) to prevent kinking

complications.prevention: Ensure adequate donor inflow, proper graft sizing
complications.management: Thrombectomy, may need iliac stent on donor side

complications.prevention: Preoperative imaging to rule out donor iliac stenosis

complications.management: Antibiotics, drainage; graft removal if deep infection

outcomes.notes: Better than axillofemoral, approaches aortobifemoral for unilateral disease

definition.@value: Extra-anatomic bypass procedure connecting the two femoral arteries across the suprapubic area for unilateral iliac occlusive disease

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.

learning_objectives: Describe the indications for femorofemoral bypass
Assess donor iliac artery adequacy preoperatively
Perform femorofemoral bypass with proper tunnel placement
Compare outcomes to other treatment options for iliac disease
clinical_pearls: The donor iliac MUST be evaluated - if it's bad, you'll create steal
Use externally supported graft to prevent compression at the pubis
A gentle C-curve in the tunnel prevents kinking
This is a great operation for unilateral disease with excellent outcomes
If both iliacs are diseased, you need aortic inflow (endovascular or open)

medicalCode.description: Bypass right femoral artery to left femoral artery with synthetic substitute
